A heavy package of mass 10 kg slides horizontally on a frictionless conveyor belt. It then collides and sticks to a lighter, stationary trolley of mass 20 kg. The combined package and trolley assembly then moves up a small ramp to a vertical height of 0.8 m. Assuming g = 10 m/s^2, determine the initial speed of the package.

During a snowball fight, a large, dense snowball of mass 0.5 kg is thrown horizontally and hits a stationary wooden target of mass 9.5 kg mounted on a small sled resting on a frictionless frozen pond. The snowball gets embedded in the target, and the combined sled and target slide up a gentle incline to a maximum vertical height of 0.1 m. Taking g = 9.8 m/s^2, what was the initial speed of the snowball?

A small dummy rocket stage of mass 200 kg moving horizontally collides with and latches onto a stationary test platform of mass 1800 kg designed to simulate a larger stage. The combined system then slides up a curved rail, reaching a maximum vertical height of 0.045 m. If g = 9.8 m/s^2, calculate the initial speed of the dummy rocket stage.

Two gliders, with masses of 0.5 kg and 0.8 kg, are placed on a frictionless air track. A light spring with a spring constant of 200 N/m is compressed by 0.15 m between them. When the gliders are released from rest, they move apart. Calculate the speed of the 0.5 kg glider just after the spring loses contact and reaches its natural length.

A main spacecraft module (1200 kg) and a smaller sub-module (300 kg) are initially latched together in deep space. A spring-loaded mechanism, with a spring constant of 5000 N/m, is compressed by 0.05 m between them. When released, the modules separate. Determine the speed of the main spacecraft module immediately after the separation mechanism fully extends.

A small projectile of mass 20 g is loaded into a launcher weighing 1.5 kg, which rests on a smooth horizontal surface. A compressed spring inside the launcher, with a constant of 150 N/m, is initially compressed by 8 cm. When the spring is released, it propels the projectile forward and causes the launcher to recoil. Calculate the speed of the projectile just as it leaves the launcher and the spring reaches its natural length.

Two toy cars, one with mass 0.3 kg and the other with mass 0.4 kg, are placed touching each other on a smooth horizontal table. A light spring with a spring constant of 50 N/m is placed between them, compressed by 0.12 m, and held by a string. When the string is cut, the cars are pushed apart. What is the speed of the 0.3 kg car immediately after the spring reaches its natural length?

Two components of a mechanical system, Component A (8 kg) and Component B (20 kg), are initially held together on a frictionless surface. A robust spring, designed for deployment, with a spring constant of 1000 N/m, is compressed by 3 cm between them. Upon activation, the spring releases and pushes the components apart. Calculate the speed of Component A as the spring reaches its natural length.

Two spacecraft, a main module of mass 5000 kg and a smaller probe of mass 500 kg, are docked together in deep space. A spring-loaded separation mechanism, with an effective spring constant of 10000 N/m, is activated, pushing them apart. If the spring was initially compressed by 0.5 meters, what is the final speed of the smaller probe relative to the initial combined center of mass?

A stationary improvised explosive device, initially at rest, explodes into two fragments of masses 2 kg and 3 kg. The chemical energy released by the explosion is equivalent to the potential energy stored in a spring with a constant of 5000 N/m compressed by 0.1 meters. Calculate the speed of the 3 kg fragment immediately after the explosion.

In a physics laboratory experiment on a frictionless air track, a 0.2 kg cart has a spring (spring constant 150 N/m) attached to its front. A second cart of mass 0.4 kg is pushed against this spring, compressing it by 0.05 meters. When the carts are released from rest, they move in opposite directions. Determine the final speed of the 0.2 kg cart.

A miniature cannon of mass 20 kg is mounted on frictionless wheels. It fires a 1 kg projectile using a powerful internal spring with a spring constant of 2000 N/m. If the spring is initially compressed by 0.2 meters before firing, what is the recoil speed of the cannon?

Two small, identical permanent magnets, one of mass 0.1 kg and the other of mass 0.2 kg, are held together on a frictionless horizontal surface with like poles facing each other, storing repulsive potential energy. This stored energy is equivalent to a spring with a constant of 200 N/m compressed by 0.01 meters. When released, they fly apart. What is the final speed of the 0.1 kg magnet?

A forklift of mass 800 kg is designed to push heavy crates. It is equipped with a front buffer system that can be modeled as a single spring with a spring constant of 50,000 N/m. The forklift approaches a 200 kg crate on a perfectly smooth factory floor. Initially, both are at rest and the spring is at its natural length. The forklift's engine applies a constant forward thrust of 2000 N to the forklift itself. What is the maximum compression achieved by the buffer spring?

In a zero-gravity environment, a large spacecraft (mass 5000 kg) attempts to dock with a smaller scientific module (mass 1000 kg). The docking mechanism can be simplified as a spring with a spring constant of 1000 N/m. Initially, the two spacecraft are at rest relative to each other, and the docking spring is completely relaxed. The larger spacecraft then applies a constant thrust of 50 N towards the module. What is the maximum compression that the docking spring will experience?

A hobbyist sets up a model train on a perfectly frictionless track. The train consists of a 0.5 kg engine and a 0.2 kg passenger car, connected by a coupling mechanism that behaves like a spring with a constant of 10 N/m. Both are initially at rest, and the coupling spring is at its natural length. The engine then exerts a constant forward pull of 2 N on itself. Determine the maximum extension of the coupling spring.

Engineers are testing a new rail-based projectile launch system. A 50 kg launcher base is on frictionless horizontal rails and connected to a 5 kg projectile carriage by a powerful spring with a spring constant of 500 N/m. The spring is initially relaxed, and the entire system is at rest. A hydraulic piston applies a constant force of 100 N to the launcher base. What is the maximum compression the spring will undergo?

In a simulated crash test, a 1200 kg car chassis is mounted on frictionless rollers. Its 80 kg front bumper assembly is connected to the chassis by a system of springs with an effective spring constant of 15,000 N/m. Initially, the car and bumper are at rest, and the bumper springs are at their natural length. A constant force of 5000 N is applied to the main chassis, simulating a controlled impact. Calculate the maximum compression experienced by the bumper springs.

An automated industrial trolley system features two carts connected by a spring. Cart A has a mass of 10 kg and Cart B has a mass of 20 kg. They are initially at rest on a smooth horizontal track, with the connecting spring unstretched. The spring constant is 500 N/m. A constant force of 150 N is applied to Cart B, pushing it forward. Determine the maximum extension of the spring during the subsequent motion.

In a physics laboratory experiment, two gliders are placed on a frictionless air track. Glider A has a mass of 0.2 kg and Glider B has a mass of 0.3 kg. They are connected by a light spring with a spring constant of 15 N/m. Initially, the gliders are at rest and the spring is at its natural length. A constant horizontal force of 0.5 N is applied to Glider B. Calculate the maximum extension the spring will experience.

During a simulated space docking maneuver in a zero-gravity environment, a smaller satellite of mass 2000 kg is to connect with a larger module of mass 5000 kg. The docking mechanism can be modeled as a spring with a spring constant of 10000 N/m. Initially, both spacecraft are relatively at rest and the mechanism is unstretched. The smaller satellite's thrusters apply a constant force of 500 N towards the larger module. Assuming the force acts only on the smaller satellite, what is the maximum compression (extension) of the docking spring?

A child's toy truck, with a mass of 1.5 kg, pulls a toy trailer of mass 0.5 kg. They are connected by a flexible coupling that behaves like a spring with a spring constant of 20 N/m. Starting from rest on a smooth floor, the truck's motor generates a constant forward force of 3 N. What will be the maximum extension of the coupling spring?

Consider a simplified model of a fault line where two massive rock layers interact. The upper layer has an effective mass of 50000 kg, and the lower layer has an effective mass of 100000 kg. These layers are connected by an elastic zone modeled as a spring with a constant of 5000 N/m. Initially, the layers are at rest, and the elastic zone is unstretched. A continuous tectonic force of 1000 N acts horizontally on the lower layer. Determine the maximum displacement (extension) that occurs within the elastic zone.

A cue ball (Ball 1) of mass 0.16 kg is moving at 8.5 m/s towards an identical, stationary 8-ball (Ball 2) on a frictionless billiard table. A rigid wall is positioned just beyond the 8-ball. All collisions are perfectly elastic. After all possible collisions have occurred between the balls and the wall, what is the final speed of the cue ball?

In a hypothetical linear particle accelerator, a proton (Particle A) with a mass of 1.67 x 10^-27 kg is propelled at a speed of 8.5 m/s, directly encountering an identical, stationary proton (Particle B). Immediately after Particle B is struck, it undergoes a perfectly elastic collision with a fixed, impenetrable atomic nucleus 'wall'. All collisions are perfectly elastic and occur in one dimension. Determine the final speed of Particle A after all collisions have ceased.

Two identical experimental modules, each with a mass of 2500 kg, are undergoing a one-dimensional test in deep space. Module X is moving at 8.5 m/s towards Module Y, which is initially at rest. A robust, fixed space station panel acts as a perfectly elastic 'wall' a short distance beyond Module Y. Assuming all collisions are perfectly elastic, what is the final speed of Module X after all interactions (module-module and module-wall) have concluded?

On a frictionless air hockey table, a red puck (Puck 1) of mass 0.02 kg slides at 8.5 m/s towards an identical blue puck (Puck 2), which is initially at rest. A sturdy, elastic bumper forms a wall at the far edge of the table, just beyond Puck 2. All collisions (puck-puck and puck-bumper) are perfectly elastic. Calculate the final speed of the red puck once all collisions have concluded.

In an automated industrial facility, a powered cart (Cart 1) of mass 150 kg travels at 8.5 m/s along a straight track towards an identical, unpowered cart (Cart 2) which is momentarily at rest. At the end of the track is a heavy, fixed buffer that acts as a perfectly elastic barrier. Assuming all collisions (cart-cart and cart-buffer) are perfectly elastic and motion is strictly one-dimensional, what is the final speed of the initially powered cart (Cart 1) after all collisions?

Two identical air hockey pucks, Puck A and Puck B, are on a frictionless table. Puck A (mass 0.15 kg) is moving at a speed of 3.5 m/s directly towards Puck B, which is initially at rest. Behind Puck B, at a short distance, is a perfectly rigid, stationary bumper. All collisions (puck-puck and puck-bumper) are perfectly elastic. What is the final speed of Puck A after all possible collisions have occurred?

Consider two identical gas molecules, Molecule X and Molecule Y, moving in a one-dimensional path. Molecule X is moving at a speed of 450 m/s towards Molecule Y, which is initially at rest. Molecule Y is positioned such that it will collide head-on with a perfectly rigid and fixed container wall after its collision with Molecule X. All collisions are perfectly elastic. Determine the final speed of Molecule X after all collisions are complete.

On a frictionless billiard table, Ball 1 is initially moving at 1.5 m/s towards an identical Ball 2, which is at rest. The initial distance between the centers of Ball 1 and Ball 2 is 0.6 m. A rigid cushion (wall) is located 0.9 m beyond Ball 2's initial position. All collisions (ball-ball and ball-cushion) are perfectly elastic. Calculate the total time elapsed from the moment of the first collision until Ball 1 returns to its initial starting position.

Two identical satellites, Satellite Alpha and Satellite Beta, each with a mass of 250 kg, are in a zero-gravity environment. Satellite Alpha is moving at 80 m/s directly towards Satellite Beta, which is initially stationary. They undergo a perfectly elastic collision. After this, Satellite Beta moves towards and collides perfectly elastically with a massive, stationary space station component (acting as a rigid wall). What is the total kinetic energy of the two-satellite system after all collisions have concluded?

Two identical pendulum bobs, P and Q, are suspended such that they can swing along a straight line and undergo head-on collisions at their lowest point. Bob P is released from rest at a height of 0.75 m above its lowest point. It swings down and collides perfectly elastically with Bob Q, which is initially at rest at its lowest point. Immediately after colliding with Bob P, Bob Q then collides perfectly elastically with a rigid, stationary barrier. Assuming Bob P can swing back along its original path, what is the maximum height above its lowest point that Bob P reaches after all collisions?

A cart of mass 2 kg moving at 5 m/s collides head-on with a 3 kg cart moving in the opposite direction at 2 m/s on a frictionless track. If the coefficient of restitution for the collision is 0.8, what is the final velocity of the 2 kg cart?

A cue ball of mass 0.17 kg is shot at 3 m/s towards a stationary 8-ball, also of mass 0.17 kg. Assuming a head-on collision and a coefficient of restitution of 0.9, determine the final velocity of the 8-ball.

A freight car with a mass of 20,000 kg traveling at 2 m/s in a railyard collides with a stationary freight car of mass 30,000 kg. If the collision is head-on and the coefficient of restitution is 0.6, find the final velocity of the 20,000 kg freight car.

A 100 kg satellite fragment traveling at 15 m/s collides head-on with a larger, defunct 500 kg satellite moving towards it at 5 m/s. If the coefficient of restitution for this impact is 0.3, what is the final velocity of the 500 kg defunct satellite?

In a game of curling, a 19 kg curling stone sliding at 1.5 m/s strikes a stationary 19 kg curling stone head-on. Given that the coefficient of restitution is 0.95, calculate the final velocity of the initially moving curling stone.

A cue ball of mass 0.17 kg moving at 3.0 m/s strikes a stationary 8-ball of identical mass head-on. If the coefficient of restitution between the balls is 0.9, calculate the final velocity of the cue ball after the collision.

A freight car of mass 20,000 kg traveling at 2.5 m/s collides head-on with a stationary freight car of mass 30,000 kg. If the coupling mechanism results in a coefficient of restitution of 0.4, determine the velocity of the heavier freight car immediately after the collision.

In a controlled crash test, Car A (mass 1500 kg) moving at 10.0 m/s collides head-on with a stationary Car B (mass 1000 kg). Assuming the collision has a coefficient of restitution of 0.4, what is the final velocity of Car A?

A small piece of space debris (mass 5 kg) is traveling at 500 m/s when it collides head-on with a larger satellite (mass 20 kg) moving in the same direction at 100 m/s. If the coefficient of restitution for this collision is 0.2, what is the velocity of the satellite immediately after impact?

A projectile of mass 0.5 kg strikes a stationary block of wood of mass 2.0 kg head-on. After the collision, the block of wood moves forward at a velocity of 2.0 m/s. If the coefficient of restitution for this impact is 0.6, what was the initial speed of the projectile?

A laboratory cart of mass 0.5 kg, moving at a speed of 3 m/s, collides head-on with an identical cart initially at rest on a frictionless track. If the coefficient of restitution for the collision is 0.8, calculate the loss of kinetic energy during the impact.

A white billiard ball (mass 0.16 kg) is struck, giving it a speed of 1.5 m/s. It then collides head-on with a stationary black billiard ball of the same mass. If the coefficient of restitution between the balls is 0.75, determine the kinetic energy dissipated during the collision.

On an ice rink, a hockey puck with a mass of 0.17 kg is shot at a speed of 5 m/s. It makes a direct, head-on collision with another identical puck that is at rest. Assuming the coefficient of restitution is 0.6, what is the total loss of kinetic energy in the system due to the collision?

A small, unladen railway wagon of mass 500 kg is moving at 0.5 m/s when it collides head-on with an identical stationary wagon. If the coupling mechanism results in a coefficient of restitution of 0.4, find the energy lost in the collision.

A piece of space debris, with a mass of 10 kg, is moving at 2 km/s when it undergoes a head-on collision with another identical piece of debris that is momentarily at rest relative to the first object's path. If the collision has a coefficient of restitution of 0.2, what is the total kinetic energy converted into other forms (e.g., heat, deformation) during the impact?

A cue ball of mass 0.17 kg, moving at a speed of 1.5 m/s, strikes a stationary 8-ball of mass 0.16 kg head-on. The coefficient of restitution for the collision is 0.8. Calculate the loss of kinetic energy during this collision.

A 1500 kg car traveling at 72 km/h collides head-on with a stationary 2000 kg truck. If the coefficient of restitution for this collision is 0.3, determine the total kinetic energy lost during the impact.

A tennis ball with a mass of 0.058 kg is served at 30 m/s and collides head-on with a stationary tennis racket. Assuming the effective mass of the racket head involved in the collision is 0.3 kg and the coefficient of restitution is 0.7, what is the loss of kinetic energy?

During a docking procedure in space, a 15000 kg supply spacecraft approaches a massive 100000 kg space station module at a relative speed of 0.5 m/s. The module is initially considered stationary. If the docking collision has a coefficient of restitution of 0.1, find the loss of kinetic energy during this 'soft' impact.

A bullet of mass 0.01 kg is fired with a speed of 300 m/s into a stationary wooden block of mass 2 kg. The collision is head-on, and the coefficient of restitution is found to be 0.2. Calculate the kinetic energy dissipated during this impact.

A billiard ball of mass 0.17 kg strikes a cushion with a speed of 3.0 m/s. The angle of incidence with the normal to the cushion is 30 degrees. If the coefficient of restitution between the ball and the cushion is 0.8, what is the speed of the billiard ball immediately after impact?

A tennis ball, with an initial speed of 25.0 m/s, hits a rigid vertical wall. The ball's trajectory makes an angle of 45 degrees with the normal to the wall. Assuming a coefficient of restitution of 0.7 for the collision, calculate the speed of the tennis ball as it rebounds from the wall.

A hockey puck slides across the ice and collides with the rink boards. Its speed before impact is 15.0 m/s, and it strikes the boards at an angle of 60 degrees relative to the normal of the board surface. If the coefficient of restitution for this collision is 0.6, determine the speed of the puck just after it leaves the boards.

A high-velocity projectile of mass 0.5 kg impacts a reinforced bunker wall. The projectile's speed before impact is 300.0 m/s, and its path makes an angle of 15 degrees with the normal to the wall. Given a coefficient of restitution of 0.2 for the collision (indicating significant deformation), what is the speed of the projectile after rebounding?

During a docking maneuver, a small spacecraft module inadvertently brushes against a deflector shield on a space station. The relative speed of the module before impact is 500.0 m/s, and its trajectory makes an angle of 75 degrees with the normal to the deflector surface. If the collision has a coefficient of restitution of 0.95, what is the angle of reflection (with respect to the normal) of the spacecraft module after impact?

A billiard ball of mass 0.17 kg is moving with a speed of 3.5 m/s when it strikes a cushion. The angle of incidence with the normal to the cushion is 60 degrees. If the coefficient of restitution between the ball and the cushion is 0.85, what is the speed of the billiard ball immediately after the collision?

A hockey puck of mass 0.16 kg is shot towards the sideboards of a rink with a speed of 20 m/s. It hits the boards at an angle of 45 degrees with respect to the normal to the board. Assuming the coefficient of restitution between the puck and the board is 0.7, calculate the angle of reflection of the puck with respect to the normal.

A small projectile of mass 0.05 kg approaches an inclined plane with a speed of 15 m/s. It strikes the plane such that its angle of incidence with the normal to the plane is 30 degrees. Given a coefficient of restitution of 0.6 for the impact, determine the speed of the projectile just after it rebounds from the inclined plane.

A compact car of mass 1200 kg skids into a rigid concrete barrier at a speed of 10 m/s. The angle its velocity vector makes with the normal to the barrier is 70 degrees. If the effective coefficient of restitution for this inelastic collision is 0.3, what will be the angle of its rebound velocity with respect to the normal?

A squash ball with a mass of 0.024 kg is served with a speed of 30 m/s, hitting the front wall of the court. The angle of incidence with the normal to the wall is 50 degrees. If the coefficient of restitution for the squash ball-wall interaction is 0.8, what is the speed of the squash ball immediately after reflecting off the wall?

A cargo pod of mass 500 kg approaches a space station's docking module with a speed of 0.5 m/s. The docking module, which has a mass of 1000 kg, is initially at rest and is connected by a strong cable to the main space station core of mass 10000 kg, acting like a counterweight over a frictionless pulley system in zero-gravity. The cargo pod docks (sticks) to the module. Find the speed of the combined cargo pod and docking module system immediately after the collision.

During a construction project, a steel beam of mass 200 kg is accidentally dropped onto a stationary platform of mass 100 kg. This platform is part of a crane system, connected by a cable over a frictionless pulley to a 300 kg counterweight. The steel beam hits the platform with a speed of 2.0 m/s and sticks to it. Determine the speed of the platform immediately after the impact.

In an underground mine, a loose boulder of mass 50 kg rolls off a ledge and falls onto an empty mining cart of mass 150 kg below. This cart is connected by a cable running over a smooth pulley to a 100 kg support cart, both initially at rest. The boulder impacts the empty cart with a speed of 3.0 m/s and immediately becomes lodged. What is the speed of the combined cart and boulder just after the collision?

An elevator car of mass 500 kg is designed with an internal load platform of mass 50 kg, which is connected via a rope over a pulley to an 800 kg counterweight. Initially, the system is at rest. A heavy toolbox of mass 15 kg is dropped from a height and lands on the load platform with a speed of 4.0 m/s, sticking to it. Calculate the speed of the load platform immediately after the toolbox impacts it.

In a specialized rock climbing setup, a climber of mass 70 kg loses grip and falls, impacting a safety platform (part of the belay system) of mass 10 kg with a speed of 5.0 m/s. This platform is connected by a rope over a smooth pulley to a stationary counterbalancing mass of 80 kg. The climber sticks to the platform. What is the speed of the platform and climber system just after the impact?

A small meteoroid of mass 0.5 kg is traveling at 200 m/s when it collides and sticks to a stationary satellite in deep space. The satellite consists of a main body with mass 100 kg and an attached scientific probe of mass 50 kg, rigidly connected to the main body. Assuming the satellite and probe move as a single unit after the impact, what is the speed of the combined satellite system just after the collision?

In an industrial setting, a 20 kg crate is dropped from a height and impacts a stationary section of a conveyor belt at a speed of 5 m/s. The crate immediately sticks to the belt. This conveyor belt section, which has a mass of 100 kg, is mechanically linked to a 80 kg counterweight by a cable and pulley system, ensuring they move together. What is the speed of the conveyor belt and counterweight system immediately after the crate sticks?

A car of mass 1500 kg is traveling at 10 m/s when it rear-ends a stationary car of mass 1200 kg. The stationary car is towing a 300 kg trailer. All three vehicles become entangled and move as a single unit immediately after the perfectly inelastic collision. What is the speed of the combined wreckage just after the impact?

During a physics demonstration, a tennis ball of mass 0.06 kg is launched horizontally at 30 m/s into a complex target. The target consists of two laboratory carts, cart A (mass 2 kg) and cart B (mass 1 kg), initially at rest on a frictionless track and connected by a light, rigid rod. The tennis ball embeds itself in cart A upon impact. What is the speed of the combined three-body system (ball + cart A + cart B) immediately after the collision?

A high-speed projectile of mass 0.01 kg is fired horizontally at 100 m/s into a stationary wooden block of mass 0.5 kg. This block is connected by a compressed spring to an identical second wooden block of mass 0.5 kg, both resting on a frictionless surface. The projectile embeds itself in the first block. Assuming the spring's internal forces are negligible during the instantaneous collision, calculate the speed of the combined two-block and projectile system just after the projectile strikes.
